thread.title: NM Film Office nominated for a global award
thread.title_full: NM Film Office nominated for a global award

author: Shelby Perea
title: NM Film Office nominated for a global award

organizations.name: ny state governor's office of motion picture development

text: Season two of "Better Call Saul," which was filmed in New Mexico, was also nominated for… more Ursula Coyote/AMC New Mexico Film Office is among 30 other television and film nominees for the Location Managers Guild International Awards. The New Mexico Film Office is nominated for Outstanding Film Commission. The film office is up against some international names: Creative Scotland, the Nevada Film Office , NY State Governor's Office of Motion Picture Development and the Royal Film Commission of Jordan. The New Mexico agency is being specifically recognized for "Hell or High Water" and "Preacher." "Hell or High Water" is nominated for Best Picture at this year's Academy Awards. Season two of "Better Call Saul," which was filmed in New Mexico, was also nominated for… more Ursula Coyote/AMC The NY State Governor's Office worked on the blockbuster "The Girl on the Train" and Royal Film Commission of Jordan worked on "Rogue One: A Star Wars Story." The film office is not the only nod new Mexico got in the nominations. The television show based on Santa Fe resident George R.R. Martin 's "Game of Thrones" was nominated for Outstanding Locations in a Period Television Series. Season two of "Better Call Saul," which was filmed in New Mexico, was also nominated for Outstanding Locations in a Contemporary Television Series. In its fourth year, the awards recognize productions in TV, film and commercials around the world for creativity and use of locations to enhance its storyline. Winners are revealed during a ceremony in April held at the Warner Bros. studio in California. There have been more than 300 film and television productions since 2002, according to the New Mexico Film Industry Office. To see some of the most recent productions, click here. According to the 2016 New Mexico Film Production Tax Incentive Study , film-induced tourism brought in an average of $539.2 million in visitor spending and an average total labor income of $206.6 million. New Mexico also had $387 million in direct spending in fiscal year 2016. Industries
